snippet: France said it would accept 24,000 asylum seekers over two years, Britain plans to accept 20,000 Syrian refugees and Germany set aside $6.7 billion to help new arrivals.
abstract: Thousands more migrants from Middle East and North Africa cross over southern border of Hungary from Serbia, exacerbating tensions; European leaders like British Prime Min David Cameron and French Pres Francois Hollande pledge to take in more refugees and asylum-seekers, but numbers under consideration still fall far short; some European countries like Hungary have balked at accepting more than token number of migrants.

byline.original: By RICK LYMAN, STEVEN ERLANGER and AURELIEN BREEDEN
byline.contributor: Rick Lyman reported from Roszke, Hungary; Steven Erlanger from London; and Aurelien Breeden from Paris. Reporting was contributed by Dan Bilefsky from London; Melissa Eddy from Berlin; Anemona Hartocollis from Rodekro, Denmark; Palko Karasz from Budapest; Helene Bienvenu from Roszke; and Raphael Minder from Madrid.

lead_paragraph: France said it would accept 24,000 asylum seekers over two years, Britain plans to accept 20,000 Syrian refugees and Germany set aside $6.7 billion to help new arrivals.

headline.main: A Steady Flow Staggers Into Europe, Outpacing Pledges of Shelter
headline.print_headline: A Steady Flow Staggers Into Europe, Outpacing Pledges of Shelter

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
